00014 #ifndef U_MULTIPART_H
00015 #define U_MULTIPART_H 1
00016 
00017 #include <ulib/container/vector.h>
00018 
00019 /*
00020 UMimeMultipartMsg -- class to build a MIME multipart
00021 
00022 A MIME-formatted message contains one or several MIME sections. MIME headers specify how multiple MIME sections
00023 are to be interpreted as a whole (whether they are attached together; whether they are alternative representations
00024 of the same content; or something even more esoteric). This manual page gives a very brief, terse, overview of basic
00025 MIME concepts. See RFC 2045, RFC 2046, RFC 2047, RFC 2048, and RFC 2049 for a formal definition of MIME-formatted messages.
00026 Each string in a MIME message is encoded as a single MIME section. A MIME section consists of at least one header line,
00027 "Content-Type:". The "Content-Type:" header gives the type of the data ontained in the string. Other header lines may
00028 also be present. Their relative order does not matter. MIME headers are followed by a blank line, then the contents of
00029 the string, encoded appropriately. All MIME sections generated by UMimeMultipartMsg will always contain another header,
00030 "Content-Transfer-Encoding:". This header gives the encoding method used for the string; it is an optional header,
00031 but UMimeMultipartMsg always creates it. The MIME encoding method defaults to "7bit" if this header is absent. 7bit
00032 encoding is only suitable for plain text messages in the US-ASCII character set. The "8bit" encoding method is used
00033 by plain text messages in other character sets that use octets with the high bit set. An alternative to 8bit encoding
00034 is "quoted-printable". The "base64" encoding method is used for string containing binary data (anything other than plain
00035 text). MIME sections that contain text messages have their "Content-Type:" header set to "text/plain"; or "text/html"
00036 for HTML messages. There are also several other, rare, content types that can be used. MIME sections that contain other
00037 kinds of data will use some other, appropriate "Content-Type:" header, such as "image/gif", or "audio/x-wav". MIME
00038 sections that contain textual content may also use the base64 encoding method, they are not required to use 7bit, 8bit,
00039 or quoted-printable. "text/pdf" sections, that contain PDF files, typically contain binary data and must use the base64
00040 encoding. Consequently, MIME sections that typically contain binary data, such as image/gif and audio/x-wav, are free
00041 to use encodings other than base64, as long as all the data can be represented by printable characters (but, in practice,
00042 that never happens). MIME sections may also contain other, optional, headers such as "Content-Disposition:", "Content-ID:",
00043 and "Content-Name:". Consult the appropriate RFCs for the specific usage of these headers. These headers can be added
00044 by UMimeMultipartMsg by using the option parameter, as described below. These headers play no part in creating the overall
00045 structure of a MIME-encoded message, and UMimeMultipartMsg does not care much about these headers. It simply includes them,
00046 and their content, upon request. Multiple string are formatted as a single message MIME message in two steps: first, by
00047 creating a MIME section for each string; and then creating a single MIME section that contains other MIME sections.
00048 A "multipart/mixed" MIME section contains a collection of MIME sections that represent different objects, attached
00049 together. A "multipart/alternative" MIME section contains a collection of MIME sections which are alternative
00050 representations of the same object, such as an HTML and a plain text version of the same message. Other "multipart"
00051 MIME sections also exist, and their usage is defined by their respective RFCs.
00052 */
00053 
00054 class U_EXPORT UMimeMultipartMsg {
00055 public:
00056         // Check for memory error
00057         U_MEMORY_TEST
00058 
00059         // Allocator e Deallocator
00060         U_MEMORY_ALLOCATOR
00061         U_MEMORY_DEALLOCATOR
00062 
00063         enum Encoding {
00064                 AUTO              = 0,
00065                 BIT7              = 1,
00066                 BIT8              = 2,
00067                 QUOTED_PRINTABLE  = 3,
00068                 BASE64            = 4
00069         };
00070 
00071         // Creating a multipart MIME collection
00072         // --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00073         // type must be either "mixed", "alternative", or some other MIME multipart content type
00074         // Additionally, "encoding" can only be "7bit" or "8bit", and will default to "8bit" if not specified
00075         // --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00076 
00077         UMimeMultipartMsg(const char* type = "mixed",
00078                                                         Encoding encoding = BIT8,
00079                                                         const char* header = "MIME-Version: 1.0");
00080 
00081         ~UMimeMultipartMsg()
00082                 {
00083                 U_TRACE_UNREGISTER_OBJECT(0, UMimeMultipartMsg)
00084                 }
00085 
00086         // VARIE
00087 
00088         UString message();
00089 
00090         // manage parts
00091 
00092         void add(const UString& section)
00093                 {
00094                 U_TRACE(0, "UMimeMultipartMsg::add(%.*S)", U_STRING_TO_TRACE(section))
00095 
00096         // U_ASSERT_EQUALS(section.find("MIME-Version: 1.0"),U_NOT_FOUND) /* con rfc822 si possono avere duplicazioni */
00097                 U_ASSERT_EQUALS(section.find(boundary+u_line_terminator_len),U_NOT_FOUND)
00098 
00099                 vec_part.push(section);
00100                 }
00101 
00102         uint32_t getNumPart() const            { return vec_part.size(); }
00103 
00104         UString operator[](uint32_t pos) const { return vec_part.at(pos); }
00105 
00106         // Creating a single MIME section
00107         // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00108         // The type option encodes content appropriately, adds the "Content-Type: type" and
00109         // "Content-Transfer-Encoding:" and MIME headers. type can be any valid MIME type, except for multipart
00110         // The encoding option should be specified. It's more efficient to do so
00111         // The charset option sets the MIME charset attribute for text/plain content
00112         // The name option sets the name attribute for Content-Type:
00113         // Additional headers are specified by the header option, doesn't do anything with them except to insert
00114         // the headers into the generated MIME section
00115         // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00116 
00117         static UString section(const UString& content,
00118                                                                   const char* type = "",
00119                                                                   Encoding encoding = AUTO,
00120                                                                   const char* charset = "",
00121                                                                   const char* name = "",
00122                                                                   const char* header = "");
00123 
00124         // STREAM
00125 
00126         friend ostream& operator<<(ostream& os, UMimeMultipartMsg& m)
00127                 {
00128                 U_TRACE(0+256, "UMimeMultipartMsg::operator<<(%p,%p)", &os, &m)
00129 
00130                 os << m.message();
00131 
00132                 return os;
00133                 }
00134 
00135         // DEBUG
00136 
00137 #ifdef DEBUG
00138         const char* dump(bool reset) const;
00139 #endif
00140 
00141 protected:
00142         char boundary[64];
00143         uint32_t boundary_len;
00144         UVector<UString> vec_part;
00145 
00146 private:
00147                          inline char* mkboundary() U_NO_EXPORT;
00148         static inline int encodeAutodetect(const UString& content, const char* charset) U_NO_EXPORT;
00149 
00150         UMimeMultipartMsg(const UMimeMultipartMsg&)            {}
00151         UMimeMultipartMsg& operator=(const UMimeMultipartMsg&) { return *this; }
00152 };
00153 
00154 #endif
